summary: Stop reading this and go play :)
reviewText: We (me and kids) found Uncharted 2 to show major improvements in every aspect over the Drake's Fortune, its predecessor. The world is bigger and more colorful, the characters are more interesting, the story is... well... more compelling and spread over several sites, the cinematic action and the interactive play blend seamlessly into each other, there's a much better mix between shooting, melees, exploration and chases, there are more weapons and... to put it shortly, if you liked Drake's Fortune then Uncharted 2 is guaranteed to blow your socks off.GAME MODESSurprisingly combat is easier than in Drake's (new weapons such as the Riot Shield help). I won't call myself an above-average gamer. I almost always start playing in the 'easy' mode and I rarely dare the 'difficult' modes but Among Thieves makes it so easy and it's so much more natural and fluid when compared with Drake's. And, without giving away anything, there's a lot more than combat in this game.In the easy mode, the hint system will point you in the right direction, most of the time. This is not exactly an open world like Oblivion or Fallout - you go from here to there and you most do A, B, C before you get to do D but it's all so much fun doing it, you often forget about the constraints.And then, of course, there's the Online modes with voice chats which we haven't had time to try yet. Online supports 5 vs. 5 multiplayer modes and up to 3 players co-op modes.Earnings from online or story mode games can be combined to purchase better weapons or equipment.Oh, and there are trophies, of course. Not to mention that you can record gameplay to show it off later.PICTURE, MOTION, SOUNDIt's a game... it's a movie... :) It's both and they blend together. The color are brighter, the vistas are vaster, the attention to detail is sometimes mind-boggling - rain-drops falling, each one producing circular ripples. Amazing. As for the sound, do surround if you can. 7.1 is well... a blast.FINAL THOUGHTSIt's a 5-star without hesitation. Just go and get it if you haven't ordered it yet. And if, like me, you are not the best gamer in the world, don't worry. Chances are you'll manage. If you have kids, buy it. They'll love you more.If there was ever a shooter-adventure game to merit '5 stars' then Uncharted 2 is, without a doubt, IT.

It has honestly been a very long time, since die hard aces have been awaiting for the latest Pilotwings game. The last one came back in 1996 when Pilotwings 64 was made for the Nintendo 64 system. Why has it taken such a very long time? I have no idea. But with so much anxiousness awaited to the new Nintendo 3DS, it has been a moment awaiting to happen for new gamers, who've have not yet gotten a chance over the years to "get their wings!" But now, that opportunity has finally been awaited for new gamers on the go, as well as die hard Pilotwings fans of all kinds. But the question is that with the long-awaited return of Pilotwings, has it lost its edge for Nintendo fans after all this time, not even close.Pilotwings Resort for the new Nintendo 3DS, handles very well as a launch game for the system. The object of the game is very simple, you earn stars to unlock missions through flying jobs, by hang glinding, by a rocket jet pack or by airplane. There are 2 modes to play through, mission modes, and free flight mode. There are several mission to play throguh from passing through rings, to popping baloons, and shooting at targets. The graphics for the game flow through very nicely, and the control is very easy to learn, after just a couple of flights. The game is very fun and also theraputic and soothing, especially flying through the free flight mode. It is easy to adjust to for new Pilotwings fans, or those who've loved the past 2 incarnations from the Nintendo 64 and Super NES eras. My one gripe about this game is that with all the gameplay, I think gamers will overlook this strong title and go to other Nintendo 3DS games like Super Street Fighter IV.Through it all, Pilotwings Resort is a fun and entertaining title that shouldn't be overlooked. It has been 15 years since the last Pilotwings title, and it is well worth the wait. It is a great game from start to finish that tests you ability to fly well, and carries well as a Nintendo 3DS launch title. Hopefully, there will be more for Pilotwings gamers that can carry through the flights soon to follow. The price is definitely right on this game, and truly is worth the effort and each flight that you master is just as fun as the next one. You definitely will get your wings and soar here.Graphics: A-Sound: BControl: B+Fun & Enjoyment: B+Overall: B+

summary: An overlooked and underappreciated gem - one of the finest third person shooters ever made
reviewText: Vanquish could have been an epic disaster.  It introduces a gameplay style that has never been done before, and the action is incredibly intense, and nearly non-stop, for the duration of its 8 hour campaign.  But one thing I learned while playing this game, is that when you have the masters of the medium, Platinum Games, behind the helm, you can rest assured that you're going to have a great action experience that is not only expertly crafted, but unlike anything you've ever played before.Vanquish is a cover-based, sci-fi third person shooter with a major twist...that twist being your ability to travel at incredibly fast speeds from place to place using your suit's boost power.  The game is structured in a way that if you stay in one place for too long, enemies will either flank or destroy your cover, so if you don't keep moving, you won't remain alive for very long.  In addition to the boost, the suit's enhanced reaction abilities allow you to seemingly slow down time in order to get precision shots with your weapons.  Both the boost and slow motion abilities use your suit's cooldown powers, so the entire game is a balancing act of not overheating your suit while causing as much destruction as possible as you move from place to place at a high speed.  Combine this with an outrageous scenario involving evil Russians on a giant space station , along with with a high pace of action that makes a Michael Bay movie look like "The English Patient", and it seems like something like this just wouldn't be able to come together without turning into a huge mess of a video game.  But Vanquish couldn't be further from that.Vanquish has some of the tightest controls I've played in any video game.  And it is due to these controls that the gameplay is able to come together so well.  Early on in the game, after going through a well made tutorial, you'll be thrust into a battle that will quickly teach you what Vanquish is all about.  You'll likely die more than a few times, but what the game smartly does is it forces you to learn how to properly play the game.  You'll not only learn that taking cover will only protect you for a brief, fleeting moment, but you'll also learn how awesome your suit's powers are.  You'll realize you don't really need the cover system too much, as you quickly learn how to harness your suit's powers bring down mobs of enemy robots in ways that will make you feel incredibly powerful.  Once you get into Vanquish's rhythm, the game is pure joy.  You'll become nearly untouchable. Also, you'll start to notice into the smaller details, like the intriguing story, the very cool, upgradable weapons that become available to you, and the different tactics required to take certain enemies down.  As it all came together for me, I realized that I was playing the most tightly-crafted, well-working shooters I'd ever played.  Not only that, but the game looks fantastic, and has an awesome soundtrack to boot.Platinum Games, following up on their incredible achievement that is Bayonetta, has really delivered the goods with Vanquish.  It is innovative, action packed, and incredibly fun to play.  Like Bayonetta did with action/beat em up games, Vanquish has really upped the ante in the third person shooter genre, and given it its own unique spin that stands apart from the rest of the pack.  It's a shame that this game didn't catch on more than it did when it released in late 2010, as it's truly an underappreciated gem in the PS3/360 catalogue, but I think time will be kind to this game's legacy.  If you love fast-paced shooters and want to play a truly innovative entry into the genre, don't miss out on Vanquish.  A truly awesome game.

summary: An excellent collection for Metal Gear Solid fans
reviewText: Disclaimer: The majority of this review will focus on Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker. Since I don't own a PSP, getting this collection was my first opportunity to play the game.The first two games in this collection are the Substance version of Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty and the Subsistence version of Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater. The first game in the collection, Sons of Liberty, comes with a few extras like a cinema mode and some alternate, non-canonical missions set in both the Tanker and Plant chapters that let you play as Solid Snake instead of just Raiden. Other than that, the game is basically unchanged from the original version, which is good for those who already loved this game as it is. As for Snake Eater, there have been even more worthwhile additions. First off, the two original games of the series released on the MSX, Metal Gear and Metal Gear 2: Solid Snake, are available to play right off the bat in Snake Eater's main menu. These are some truly old school games and therefore are quite different from the newer games in the Metal Gear Solid series, although it's interesting to see how certain elements from these two older games managed to still work effectively in the newer ones. The most significant addition to Snake Eater though is the inclusion of a fully adjustable camera. The original version of Snake Eater used the classic fixed camera with the top-down view from the earlier games, but it made being stealthy a rather frustrating experience since you couldn't see far away enemies or even around corners. It simply didn't go well with the larger environments of the game. Fortunately, the camera in the Subsistence version of Snake Eater is just like the one from Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots and it made the game much more enjoyable.The third game in this collection is Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker, a game that I'm surprised wasn't just immediately released on PS3 instead of the PSP. This game takes place 10 years after Snake Eater and 4 years after the other PSP title Metal Gear Solid: Portable Ops (a game that I actually wish was included in this collection). The man known as Big Boss has just begun building his own mercenary force known as Militaires Sans Frontieres (Soldiers Without Borders) and takes a job from a man named Professor Galvez and his young female protégé named Paz, who require some help in removing an armed group of invading mercenaries from Costa Rica. Initially hesitant about taking the job, evidence is presented on the possibility of Big Boss's mentor, The Boss, still being alive, so Big Boss jumps on the opportunity to find out the truth behind this unexpected development. Again, as with any other Metal Gear Solid game, the story in Peace Walker is very in-depth and full of twists and secrets, although it's also more straightforward and somewhat easier to follow than the stories in some of the earlier games. The story moves along through comic book styled cutscenes (word bubbles and all) and many of them have interactive quick time events included in them. There are also lots of audio recordings that are acquired as the game progresses that reveal plenty of interesting background information and other juicy details. The stealth in this game is basically a mix of the usual fare from the previous games, namely the smaller environments and more plentiful cover of MGS and MGS 2 combined with the use of more basic camouflage to hide from enemies like in MGS 3 and MGS 4. In any case, expect lots of sneaking around and taking out bad guys unseen, although there is a much stronger emphasis on using non-lethal force to subdue your enemies which allows you to then recruit them and have them join Big Boss's MSF group. The way the recruitment is done is quite unique. After knocking out an enemy, Big Boss can attach a small parachute/balloon to the enemy's hip and then they go shooting up into the air to be collected by a passing helicopter (a.k.a.: Fulton Recovery). As outlandish as this is, it proves to be quite humorous. It's also not simply a gameplay element, they even manage to work it into the cutscenes with some rather hilarious results.Combat is also mostly unchanged from the way it was in the previous games; you will be laying waste to lots of enemies by using handguns, assault rifles, sniper rifles, missile launchers, grenades, etc. A new addition is the ability to call for supply drops and air strikes (it's possible one of these things was already included in Portable Ops, but I never got to play that game). You can even choose whether you want the controls to be laid out so that they resemble the controls in either MGS 4, Portable Ops, or one of the Monster Hunter games. Aside from the main missions (Main Ops) that drive the story forward and usually involve Big Boss sneaking through enemy territory or taking out attack teams and military vehicles, there are plenty of side missions (Extra Ops) to undertake which cover a wide range of objectives. Most of them are timed and include missions such as target practice, using Fulton Recovery on a certain number of enemies, locating hidden documents, protecting friendly targets, and fighting more heavily armed enemies and vehicles. These enemy vehicles, mainly APCs, tanks, and choppers, can also be captured and added to your own personal collection, just like enemy soldiers. This leads to the most significant change included in this game: base management. The main base of operations for MSF, known as Mother Base, goes through many changes as you add more recruits. Mother Base has several teams that operate within it and the success of the teams depends on how many soldiers you put in each of them (their skill levels are important factors as well). For example, putting enough soldiers in the combat unit lets you gain more experience points (GMP) that can be spent towards developing better weapons and equipment to use during missions as they become available to you. You can even play as one of the combat unit soldiers in the Extra Ops (in fact, some of these missions require you to play as one of these soldiers instead of as Big Boss). Also, soldiers in the combat unit can be sent on Outer Ops (more on that later). Putting enough soldiers in the R&D; team is what gives you access to the previously mentioned weapons and equipment. Putting enough soldiers in the medical team lets you make sure that any sick or injured soldiers will get better more quickly and gives you access to more potent healing items. In short, the more skilled soldiers you have in each team, the more smoothly things will go for you.As for the Outer Ops, they are basically special missions where your soldiers are sent to attack other enemy forces. Aside from choosing which soldiers or vehicles to send on Outer Ops, you have no direct control over how they turn out. When an Outer Op has ended, you are treated to a little video showing how the battle went. These are not fully animated videos showing your soldiers fighting other soldiers, instead what plays out on the screen is basically a combination of a digital chess match and a turn-based RPG. You'll see the icons of your soldiers and vehicles on one side of the screen and the icons of the enemy forces on the other side. Then, the soldiers and vehicles on each side will attack one another one by one. The first side to lose all available soldiers and vehicles loses, while the other side, of course, wins. Even if your side wins the battle, it is entirely possible for your soldiers and vehicles to come back wounded or damaged, and it's even possible for them to be killed or destroyed. While this all may sound somewhat overwhelming and complicated, leading your soldiers and managing Mother Base is actually quite easy to get a handle on and is really accessible to even newbie gamers. In fact, even if you're not that into playing video games, anyone looking to start their own business would do well to play this game simply to learn the basics of proper resource management. There is also a co-op element in this game where other players can join you online and assist you in missions. Being a mostly single player type of gamer myself, I didn't make use of this feature, but for those of you who are interested, it's there and it apparently works well.Peace Walker is indeed a very interesting take on the Metal Gear Solid series and brings some interesting innovations to the table, but there are a few nagging issues as well. For one thing, in typical RPG-type fashion, most of the boss fights are rather long and drawn out since they're all against armored vehicles, tanks, choppers, and the occasional giant robot; plus, they all possess extraordinarily long health bars. One of the final bosses in particular was especially frustrating...in fact, the word "frustrating" hardly does it justice. I almost gave up on it entirely. While this particular boss and a lot of the other later ones are optional, you actually do need to complete them if you want to see the true ending of the game. Yes, there's an initial ending and then a second true ending that can only be seen after completing all Main Ops and all Extra Ops (excluding some secret Extra Ops). The thing is, most of the missions after the first ending are made up of a lot of the same stuff that you've already done through the earlier parts of the game, and there are a lot of them to complete. It's basically a bunch of filler to make the game longer, which it didn't really need since the main game is easily about twice as long as all the previous Metal Gear Solid games. To make matters worse, in order to face the true final boss, there's a particular mission you have to complete first, but the game gives you absolutely no clue on how to even access this mission; I never would have found out how to get to it without checking for the solution online. Hopefully, these issues will be addressed in the upcoming sequel Metal Gear Solid: Ground Zeroes, assuming that game ends up having a similar mission structure. As it is, Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker dragged on a bit too much for my taste, especially when you compare it to the other games in the series, and this is coming from someone who has played several RPGs in his time. Regardless, this is still a great game and it's definitely worth looking into. On its own, Peace Walker gets 4 stars overall and 5 stars for fun.The Metal Gear Solid HD Collection is worth buying just for Peace Walker alone at its current price (especially if you're like me and don't own a PSP). When you combine it with the other two games in this collection, it's a no-brainer for MGS fans. Get it now if you haven't already.

summary: Nice until the Novelty wears off
reviewText: Yes when you pick up the wiimote for the first time and play Wii Sports you are going to think its pretty nifty. But it won't take long until you get tired of all those minigames and shaking the controller around in Zelda until you just want to use a normal control pad again. Then you are going to start to realize that the Wii is very limited graphics wise and most games barely look better then gamecube games at launch. Sure you are going to have some fun for a little while...until you go over to your friends house and see Gears of War on the 360 in HD for the first time. Then its going to sink in....why oh why did you give into the hype of the wiimote? Does shaking that thing around really make games like Dragon Ball Z and Marvel Ultimate Alliance any better? If you read reviews the answer to that is no.  So keep a clear head...and don't give into the hype. Nintendo is reselling you a gamecube in a new box...don't be a fool. Save up some cash and get a real next gen console. Either the XBOX 360 or PS3 will do.

reviewText: I bought the GOTY Edition when it was on sale for around $12 (new) and I must say I have had a fun time with it. This game really has a lot of twists and turns to it ..... I've played several game series like Halo, COD, GTA & all of the Assassins Creed's but this game stands alone in a class by itself. Even the decisions you make during your quests ... whether its in conversations with who you meet or how you handle your objectives, the game shifts in the direction you want it to go. This is the first time I have played a game by Bethesda and this is a winner to me.Controls are pretty smooth and graphics hold up quite well for a 2008 title. I have encountered a few glitches but they have been far and few between. Ammunition really must be conserved and you must scrounge around (explore) to find it many cases. The traders don't sell a lot so you need to be "efficient" or use good tactics when taking down foes who are much stronger. Blazing guns doesn't seem to be a good strategy based on my own experience so far. As silly as it sounds one of my favorite things to do is lie and see if they believe me !!  Its great when you gain XP and good karma when you can lie your way into a peaceful settlement with a foe. I do need to get my science skill up though since I have been unable to unlock some computer terminals. I'm sure "cracking" those would make my quests easier.If you want something different that will keep you on the edge of your seat then you owe it to yourself to go buy this game. Its kept me busy for hours already and I have a long ways to go. I look forward to installing the DLC at some point but I have enough on my plate for now. AAA+ Game - Highly Recommended.

summary: A nuclear blast with a look to the past
reviewText: Simply put, this is one of the best games I've played (right up there with HL2 even!). The Capital Wastelands is a huge open world providing many hours of completely absorbing fun. The story is staple SF stuff but the multiple quests required to complete it, along with the equally numerous side quests, make it satisfying enough. What's so impressive is the sheer scale and immersive quality of the world created by Bethesda. You can wander for hours around the Wastelands. I completed every single quest in the main game plus the 5 DLCs that come with the GOTY edition, then went in search of every bobblehead and every behemoth I hadn't already encountered, and now I'm finishing off the unlisted quests -- so far I've spent almost 170 hours in this game and have enjoyed every minute of it. The graphics are very good, if not quite on a par with very recent games. The voice acting is good throughout (one would expect no less from the likes of Liam Neeson), and the dialogue trees are often large and humorous. Also worth mentioning is the inspired retro design and use of music from the 1930s and 40s. The only downside is that it's a little unstable under Windows 7 (but you can't blame Bethesda for that, as it was created before the release of the operating system). If only all computer games were as good as this. Excellent.
The wii controler works perfectly, I did not face any issues during configuration.An excellent product with a fair price.

reviewText: I absolutely loved Allied Assault so I also was extremely excited to hear about Spearhead. I agree with everyone else who says that the game is too short but can you honestly say that this expansion or basically extra missions which is about what the expansion pack amounts to were not extremely FUN!!! Personally I found some of the missions to be the best of the entire allied assault game period, for example the stage where you blow the bridge up. I mean sure the game is pretty short, but it's not pathetic or anything. I personally am extremely satisfied with Spearhead and feel that I got my money's worth.I also love to play online as well and have not noticed any lag issues that some of you speak of. I do run a cable modem, but is that not what you were referring to? I have no lag what so ever. The new multiplayer missions are the bomb! I highly recommend this game to anyone who loved MOHAA. I personally give the game 5 stars. However I can see where some people may have been disappointed with the length of the game. The bare minimum that this game would ever deserve is 3 1/2 stars, and that would have to be from someone who really doesn't care for MOH. Plain and simple, for me at least, Medal of Honor Allied Assault with Spearhead Expansion is my personal favorite game PERIOD. The only other expansion pack that could change my mind in the upcoming near future would have to be the Wolfenstein expansion, time will tell, I do hope that there is a little more to that however.

summary: Call of Duty: Black Ops - Review
reviewText: Call of Duty is a name well known in the video game world.  The game is released every year or two and each release brings with it tremendous sales and an insanely loyal (when they get what they want) online fan base.  Modern Warfare 2 from developer Infinity Ward was a success but didn't receive the critical praise it's predecessor garnered.  With Treyarch's turn to woo the world at hand with a new game, will they succeed or are they forever doomed to be that other development company behind Infinity Ward.I'm probably one of the only people in the world who buys Call of Duty games for the single player experience.  I view the multiplayer as an added bonus that I play, but I'm mainly interested in the single player component first and foremost.  With that said, this review is going to focus primarily on the single player first and then I'll cover the multiplayer.  To date, I've beaten the campaign on normal difficulty and played about 5-6 hours of online multiplayer including zombie mode.  So, how does the game stack up compared to others?  In my opinion, it's the best yet.The single player story begins with your character (Mason) tied up in a room with TV screens all around you.  Someone from an overhead viewing window is yelling at you to remember some set of numbers.  After some introductions between the two characters and Mason realizing he's capture, you begins to flashback to the past at certain points in Mason's life, all circling around the Cold War and all playing a part to tell the story.  The first area you go to is Cuba where you are on a mission to kill Castro during the Bay of Pigs.  When you are finished the mission, you are whisked back to the interrogation room in current time.  The game is played through a sort of flashback segments that work incredibly well to tell the story.  Gone are the days of long hikes in a field to get to the next objective...instead, you are just transported there due to a memory jump.  Think of it sort of like Assassin's Creed but not exactly.During the story, you'll control a couple characters, but Mason is the main one.  I've heard some reviewers say that since you flash to and from a lot that you never get invested in the characters and their story but I didn't find that to be true.  I was definitely invested in the story from the get go and felt for each character.  The story overall though is the best you've ever seen in a Call of Duty game.  I'm a huge story fanatic when it comes to video games and I found myself looking forward to cutscene after cutscene to see what was going to happen next.  The story is great, but you might see the end twist coming a mile away like I did.  Still, it's a great story and it's a welcome addition to the series.The gameplay is the same formula you know and love from the Call of Duty franchise, except with the story set anywhere from 1948 to 1968 in the Cold War, you're going to be using a lot of different guns.  But, since you are an elite Black Ops team member, you'll have access to some weapons that others have never heard of for the times, like a shotgun that has exploding bullets that set targets on fire.  Something else that was more prominent in this game vs. the others was the use of vehicles.  There's some driving sequences but the really fun stuff takes place in the air in helicopters.  There's also a level where you start in a spy plane scouting the ground for a team trying to advance in a snow storm.  They can't see so they need you to guide them.  You have to navigate them around enemies and patrols and if they engage anyone the action zooms into the team and you take over for them.  This was an awesome mission that I really enjoyed, although it was short.  The combat in Black Ops is very similar to the other games so if you liked those, you'll be fine with this one as well.The entire story will last you around 6-8 hours depending on how you play it.  I tend to take my time and explore areas so it lasted longer for me.  Just because the single player game is short though, don't think you won't get your money.  Besides multiplayer (which I'll cover soon) there are other features included on the disc.  For starters, Zombie mode returns with the same winning formula that got it so much attention the first time around.  For those of you who aren't familiar with the mode, you play someone stuck in a building with zombies trying to get in.  You shoot to kill while also bording up windows and unlocking new areas to keep you safe.  Each kill nets you money which can be used to open up said areas or unlock new weapons.  It's great fun and you can even do it with a few other people.  I would have liked to see some more changes to it since it basically is the same game as before, but there is one awesome change they made that you'll see as soon as you beat the campaign.  I won't ruin the surprise.Something else included with the game is a top down shooter that can be unlocked from the main menu.  You need to break out of your restraints on the main menu by rapidly hitting the right and left triggers.  When you stand up, make your way to the computer and interact with it.  You can enter in two codes, DOA and zork.  DOA opens the top down shooter that is co-op enabled and something I would have gladly paid 10 bucks for on the marketplace.  The other is zork, a MUD that you probably won't play ever again after messing with it for a couple seconds.  Both open a new achievement though, so, you're welcome for the codes.The graphics in the game are nice, but nothing spectacular.  It looks like the engine they used in previous games hasn't been tweaked much since the models and explosions look very similar.  This isn't bad, just nothing new.  I did see some screenshot and video comparisons of the 360 version and PS3 and the 360 version is easily discernible as the better graphical version.  The only reason I say this is if you are like me and have both consoles and you want the better looking one, the Xbox 360 is the way to go with this one.  But, if you don't pay for Xbox Live, the choice is already made up for you.  Just something to keep in mind.Ok, on to the multiplayer.  The multiplayer this time around got a pretty big overhaul in terms of Call of Duty changes.  You still level up just like in previous iterations, but the levels come a lot faster.  Instead of unlocking weapons and perks at specific levels, you earn currency in the rounds that you use to buy items.  So, when you hit a certain level a bunch of weapons/perks, etc. become available for purchase all at once.  You then level up and earn money which you can then go and buy the one you want.  Hardcore fans of the multiplayer might be disappointed with the change, but I think it's a welcome addition.  I'm not a huge multiplayer fan because of the time sink involved.  With this new method, I can get to a level, earn some cash, and then buy my favorite weapon instead of having to level up a ton more to get it.  You get what you want, when you want it, in the order you want it.  You'll still have things to look forward to since certain weapons are only available at different levels.  Along with these changes, there is also a theatre mode (like Halo has with it's forge) where you can watch gameplay videos from your games and then change camera angles, save, and upload to the net for others to see.  I haven't played with this yet, but I did view some from other people.  The community is already taking part in it and it looks to be a defining feature of the online game experience.The customization is another aspect of the multiplayer game that has been adjusted.  Your first perk you choose decides what your character will look like.  You actually get to see a ragdoll of your character and you can change the perk to change the look.  You're going to pick the perk you like best and not the look but it's still near to see your character before going into the game.  Before, weapons decided the look, now it's the first perk.Another new feature to the online multiplayer is the wager system.  As I stated before, you earn money from rounds to buy things.  Well, if you are a gambling man, you can bet money to win more money.  There are a couple new modes (which I haven't tried out yet so I'll keep this brief) which allow you to bet money to place in the top 3.  These modes include things like "One in the Chamber" where you get one bullet and a knife to kill everyone.  Kill someone, and get another bullet.  Others involve bow and arrows and incremental guns with each kill.  This is going to be a fan favorite for a lot of people do to the very competitive nature of the games.  But, if you aren't that great at multiplayer but still want to bet a little, you can do the contract system.  With these, you pay to accept a contract and then try to meet it within the time frame.  For instance, the one I took yesterday had me pay 50 bucks to get 10 kills in the next round.  When I did, I won my money back plus some.  It's a neat system that people are going to love.  If you don't, just ignore it since it won't affect you.Call of Duty: Black Ops is a huge game.  So huge, that you would expect all of it's features to come on two discs, but they don't.  Treyarch has gone above and beyond the "call" to make something that is not only a great game, but is their own.  This is the game that sets them apart from Infinity Ward.  World at War was a great game, but there was still a feeling leaving them as the other developer.  That sentiment is now gone with Treyarch's love and affection put into a game that is the pinnacle of the series.  Black Ops is hands down the best Call of Duty to date.

description: The Next Evolution in Pokemon comes to Nintendo 3DS.
summary: This brought me out of Pokemon Retirement
reviewText: That is right, the last Pokemon game I played was Soulsilver because I originally played the Silver many years ago and never went to Black and White.  This game, while does have the same basic story line as all the others really brings new ideas, areas and of course new Pokemon as well as old favorites.  The Kalos region seems to be a cental location to all the other 5 areas (Kanto, Jhoto, Hoen, Sinnou, and Unova) which has more of a European flair than Japanese like the past installments (though given the diversity there is a Japanese area).  I love the fact you can customize your character with new clothes, ways to VR train your pokemon, and or course new ways to travel (skates enter the picture as well as riding certain Pokemon), the graphics are amazing and do POP in 3d mode.  And the new battle animations are more enjoyable than the past games - the only gripe i have on this is the fact only Pikachu (I know the most recognized and famous Pokemon known)has a voice, all the others use simple bit sounds (though they try to sound like their names)and the new air combat and horde modes bring new ways to fight and catch pokemon.  Overall I give this a major thumbs up and while only got my first badge, can not wait to see what new things the Kalos region brings.GOT TO CATCH THEM ALL!!!!!!!
